text: Introduction
label: H4

text: Money Smart for Small Business (MSSB) is an instructor-led curriculum developed jointly by the Federal
label: BODY

text: Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) and the U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA). The 13 modules in
label: BODY

text: this curriculum provide introductory business training for aspiring and existing entrepreneurs on the basics of
label: BODY

text: starting and growing a business. In addition, the curriculum serves as a foundation for more advanced training
label: BODY

text: and technical assistance.
label: BODY

text: The MSSB Curriculum was created to assist financial institutions and community organizations (Small Business
label: BODY

text: or Economic Development Organizations, Community Banks, Financial Institutions, Government Programs,
label: BODY

text: Chambers of Commerce, Business Chambers/Trade Associations and Independent Small Business Consultants)
label: BODY

text: deliver introductory business training. The FDIC and SBA invite financial institutions and community
label: BODY

text: organizations to order and begin teaching this free curriculum.
label: BODY

text: The MSSB Curriculum is a tool for partnerships. For example, financial institution staff can deliver a MSSB
label: BODY

text: Program in collaboration with small business resource providers.
label: BODY

text: The topics in the MSSB Curriculum were selected through focus groups and interviews with small business
label: BODY

text: technical assistance practitioners.
label: BODY

text: About This Participant Guide
label: H4

text: This Train-the-Trainer Participant Guide is designed to help financial institutions and community organizations
label: BODY

text: conduct effective Money Smart for Small Business introductory business training for aspiring and existing
label: BODY

text: entrepreneurs in their communities.
label: BODY

text: This guide includes complementing information to the Train-the-Trainer PowerPoint presentation, a matrix
label: BODY

text: summarizing the 13 MSSB modules, a Participant Guide, Instructor Guide and PowerPoint presentation for the
label: BODY

text: “Managing Cash Flow” module to showcase how the three components of all 13 MSSB modules interact; and a
label: BODY

text: comprehensive Success Tips section. A glossary of terms is also provided to explain the use of specific terms
label: BODY

text: within the context of the MSSB TtT Curriculum. Words in italic can be found in the MSSB TtT Curriculum
label: BODY

text: Glossary of Terms.
label: BODY

text: MSSB: Train-the-Trainer Learning Objectives
label: H4

text: After completing a Train-the-Trainer Workshop, you will be able to:
label: BODY

text: 1. Register as a MSSB Alliance member, order the 13 modules on CD-ROM or download the modules,
label: BODY

text: which include an Instructor Guide, Participant Guide and PowerPoint presentation for each module.
label: BODY

text: 2. Present the MSSB Curriculum with confidence and describe effective ways to make the content of each
label: BODY

text: module compelling and engaging.
label: BODY

text: 3. List and describe at a high level, the goals and objectives of the MSSB Curriculum.
label: BODY

text: 4. Describe several ways to customize a MSSB program to meet the diverse needs of small business owners
label: BODY

text: who represent a range of business development stages and learning needs.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: Page 5 of 92
label: BODY

text: 5. Describe best practices for working with subject matter experts to co-train modules and evaluating the
label: BODY

text: quality and impact of the MSSB Program within the MSSB Alliance Member network.
label: BODY

text: 6. Identify several ways to connect MSSB Training participants to additional training or technical
label: BODY

text: assistance by providing resources and success tips to ensure MSSB Instructors host a successful MSSB
label: BODY

text: training program.
label: BODY

text: MSSB: What It Is
label: HH2

text: MSSB is an instructor-led business curriculum or tool collaboratively developed by the FDIC and SBA that
label: BODY

text: provides introductory business training for aspiring and existing entrepreneurs on the basics of starting and
label: BODY

text: growing a business.
label: BODY

text: In 2012, the FDIC and SBA created 10 modules that cover a wide range of business topics.
label: BODY

text: In 2015, three new modules were created and all 13 modules were translated into Spanish and made available
label: BODY

text: for download.
label: BODY

text: Each module takes between 60-90 minutes to present and includes three components: an Instructor Guide, a
label: BODY

text: Participant Guide and PowerPoint.
label: BODY

text: The modules are instructor led; can be edited or customized; delivered as stand-alone modules; mixed and
label: BODY

text: matched to meet the specific needs of entrepreneurs; and integrated into the training programs that financial
label: BODY

text: institutions and community organizations currently utilize to create a lasting impact in their communities.
label: BODY

text: MSSB: Why It Was Created
label: HH2

text: MSSB was created as a tool to:
label: BODY

text: Assist financial institutions and community organizations to engage and assist aspiring and existing
label: BODY

text: entrepreneurs.
label: BODY

text: Help aspiring and existing entrepreneurs think through their business model, and to start and grow their
label: BODY

text: businesses.
label: BODY

text: Have sustainable impact in all types of communities from urban to rural.
label: BODY

text: Spur economic activity.
label: BODY

text: MSSB: Who Can Benefit
label: HH2

text: Financial Institutions and Community Organizations
label: BODY

text: Small Business or Economic Development Organizations
label: BODY

text: Community Banks/Financial Institutions
label: BODY

text: Government Programs
label: BODY

text: Chambers of Commerce or Business Chambers/Trade Associations
label: BODY

text: Independent Small Business Consultants
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide

label: BODY

text: Aspiring and Existing Entrepreneurs
label: BODY

text: • Aspiring entrepreneurs have many questions, passion, determination and fears. They need a solid
label: BODY

text: foundation to successfully start and grow a business.
label: BODY

text: • Existing entrepreneurs have successfully started their business, but as their business grows, they have
label: BODY

text: growing business demands including different skill sets.
label: BODY

text: Urban and Rural Communities
label: BODY

text: • Communities, both urban and rural, can benefit from Money Smart for Small Business.
label: BODY

text: MSSB: How They Benefit
label: HH2

text: Financial Institution and Community Organization Benefits
label: BODY

text: They become a catalyst for innovation and job creation in their community.
label: BODY

text: They become a catalyst for revitalizing a local economy.
label: BODY

text: They anchor themselves to the communities where they operate and serve.
label: BODY

text: Financial institutions may receive positive consideration under the Community Reinvestment Act
label: BODY

text: (CRA) (except credit unions and loan funds, which are not subject to the CRA Regulation).
label: BODY

text: If the organizations offering MSSB are Certified Development Financial Institutions (CDFIs), they may
label: BODY

text: be able to establish or enhance MSSB programs to meet the needs of low to moderate-income
label: BODY

text: businesses.
label: BODY

text: Aspiring Entrepreneur Benefits
label: BODY

text: Build a business and create wealth
label: BODY

text: Understand skills required in a startup
label: BODY

text: Use MSSB modules as input to develop a business plan
label: BODY

text: Existing Entrepreneur Benefits
label: BODY

text: Learn skills in maintaining a business
label: BODY

text: Learn skills in business management and operations
label: BODY

text: Ability to find more advanced training or access other resources and services
label: BODY

text: Community Benefits
label: BODY

text: Revitalized local economies and create more jobs
label: BODY

text: Wealth created by aspiring and existing entrepreneurs tends to stay in the community through
label: BODY

text: reinvestment.
label: BODY

text: Jobs created keep talent in the community. Job seekers don’t need to leave the community.
label: BODY

text: Entrepreneurs in rural areas are more likely to become community leaders and reinvest through
label: BODY

text: philanthropy and volunteer work.
label: BODY

text: As the economy grows, so does civic pride and community spirit.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: MSSB: Curriculum Components
label: H4

text: There are three components to each of the 13 modules. Every module is formatted and structured the same way.
label: BODY

text: The components of each module consist of:
label: BODY

text: A fully scripted Instructor Guide in Word and PDF formats.
label: BODY

text: A Participant Guide in Word and PDF formats.
label: BODY

text: Overhead slides (visuals) in PowerPoint and PDF formats.
label: BODY

text: The Instructor Guide is your roadmap for presenting the modules. It includes:
label: BODY

text: The purpose and objectives of the module.
label: BODY

text: A detailed lesson plan.
label: BODY

text: A copy of the overhead slides (visuals).
label: BODY

text: The topics for the training modules provide a practical introduction to aspects of starting and growing a
label: BODY

text: business that can be taught in any order or independently in 60 to 90 minutes each. In addition to grounding
label: BODY

text: participants in the basics, the curriculum serves as a foundation for more advanced training and technical
label: BODY

text: assistance.
label: BODY

text: MSSB: Curriculum Modules
label: H4

text: The first ten modules, launched in 2012, were:
label: BODY

text: Banking Services
label: BODY

text: Record Keeping
label: BODY

text: Credit Reporting
label: BODY

text: Risk Management
label: BODY

text: Financial Management
label: BODY

text: Selling a Business and Succession Planning
label: BODY

text: Insurance
label: BODY

text: Tax Planning
label: BODY

text: Organizational Types
label: BODY

text: Time Management
label: BODY

text: The three newly created modules are:
label: BODY

text: Is Small Business Ownership a Good Fit for You?
label: BODY

text: Planning for a Healthy Business
label: BODY

text: Managing Cash Flow
label: BODY

text: The original 10 modules are 60 minutes long. The three new modules are 90 minutes long and contain case
label: BODY

text: studies and interactive tools.
label: BODY

text: Please look at the Appendix:  MSSB Modules Matrix to learn more about each module.
label: BODY

text: Banking Services
label: BODY

text: The “Banking Services” module will introduce banking products and services available to entrepreneurs and
label: BODY

text: small business owners, including business checking, payroll processing, merchant services, business loans and
label: BODY

text: cash management services.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: Page 8 of 92
label: BODY

text: This module also explains how to select the best banking products and services for their business.
label: BODY

text: At the end of the module, entrepreneurs will:
label: BODY

text: Gain a solid understanding of the banking products and services available to small business owners
label: BODY

text: Understand the importance of building effective long-term relationships with a banker or lender
label: BODY

text: Recognize the role of a personal credit score in the lending process
label: BODY

text: It may be best for business owners at early stages or those who are seeking a loan from a financial institution.
label: BODY

text: The most important aspect of this module is to emphasize that entrepreneurs should start a relationship with a
label: BODY

text: financial institution well before they need a loan.
label: BODY

text: Credit Reporting
label: BODY

text: The “Credit Reporting” module highlights the impact of credit reports on the operation and growth of a business
label: BODY

text: and the impact that the business owner’s personal credit can have on it.
label: BODY

text: It identifies credit reports and other systems used to assess the risk of extending credit to entrepreneurs and
label: BODY

text: small business owners.
label: BODY

text: At the end of the module, entrepreneurs will:
label: BODY

text: Understand the full scope of credit reporting and the impact of credit reports on the operation or growth
label: BODY

text: of a small business
label: BODY

text: Discover strategies for building or improving business credit
label: BODY

text: Appreciate how personal credit scores impact the ability of a business to get credit
label: BODY

text: It may be best for companies in all stages of business development, especially for those who may have concerns
label: BODY

text: about their credit scores and/or those who plan to apply for loans.
label: BODY

text: There’s plenty of content provided by various organizations about personal credit scores, but this module may
label: BODY

text: be one of a few resources related to business credit.
label: BODY

text: Some financial institutions and community organizations use this module as a stand-alone module or as a
label: BODY

text: complement to other business development initiatives. Others have used it as part of a one-day session where
label: BODY

text: the “Credit” and “Banking” modules were taught in partnership with financial institutions and credit counseling
label: BODY

text: organizations.
label: BODY

text: Financial Management
label: BODY

text: The “Financial Management” module identifies financial management practices, rules and tools commonly
label: BODY

text: available for small businesses and how they all work.
label: BODY

text: At the end of the module, entrepreneurs will:
label: BODY

text: Grasp the importance of sound financial management
label: BODY

text: Understand small business financial management basics including:
label: BODY

text: Startup financing
label: BODY

text: o Financing for a growing business
label: BODY

text: o Financing working capital
label: BODY

text: o Financing fixed assets
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: Page 9 of 92
label: BODY

text: It may be best for companies in all stages of business development, especially business owners who are
label: BODY

text: interested in obtaining a loan from a financial institution.
label: BODY

text: Insurance
label: BODY

text: The “Insurance” module identifies the types of insurance that small businesses should understand and consider.
label: BODY

text: At the end of the module, entrepreneurs will:
label: BODY

text: Recognize the importance of small business insurance
label: BODY

text: Understand the full range of insurance products and services
label: BODY

text: o Required coverage
label: BODY

text: o Other coverage
label: BODY

text: It may be best for companies in all stages of business development, especially those who don’t yet have
label: BODY

text: insurance or find some insurance terms and concepts confusing.
label: BODY

text: Organizational Types
label: BODY

text: The “Organizational Types” module analyzes the most common legal entities or structures.
label: BODY

text: At the end of the module, entrepreneurs will:
label: BODY

text: Know that the legal structure of a business determines how a company operates and is taxed
label: BODY

text: Distinguish the general characteristics, advantages and disadvantages of organizational types:
label: BODY

text: o Sole proprietorship
label: BODY

text: o Partnerships
label: BODY

text: o Limited liability company
label: BODY

text: o C-corporation
label: BODY

text: o S-corporation
label: BODY

text: It may be best for companies in early stages of business development, especially those who have not yet
label: BODY

text: incorporated and may be confused by the risks and benefits of each organizational type.
label: BODY

text: Statistics show that the majority of small businesses operate as sole proprietorships. Business owners need to
label: BODY

text: understand how to protect themselves and their business assets.
label: BODY

text: Record Keeping
label: BODY

text: The “Record Keeping” module identifies practical record-keeping techniques.
label: BODY

text: At the end of the module, entrepreneurs will:
label: BODY

text: Comprehend the necessity for good record keeping
label: BODY

text: Learn about small business record-keeping practices and rules
label: BODY

text: Discover record keeping software tools
label: BODY

text: It may be best for companies in all stages of business development, especially those who lack formal record-
label: BODY

text: keeping disciplines.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: Page 10 of 92
label: BODY

text: Risk Management
label: BODY

text: The “Risk Management” module identifies the common risks associated with a small business and how to
label: BODY

text: manage those risks.
label: BODY

text: At the end of the module, entrepreneurs will:
label: BODY

text: Understand the common risks associated with a small business
label: BODY

text: Identify the external and internal factors which affect risk for a small business
label: BODY

text: Implement, monitor and evaluate a risk management plan for a small business
label: BODY

text: It may be best for companies in all stages of business development, especially those who want to learn about
label: BODY

text: minimizing internal and external risks to their business.
label: BODY

text: This module could be considered a more in-depth version of a SWOT (Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities
label: BODY

text: and Threats) analysis and it may work well if combined with the Insurance Module.
label: BODY

text: Selling a Business and Succession Planning
label: BODY

text: The “Selling a Business and Succession Planning” module explains how to establish an exit strategy for a
label: BODY

text: business through either a sale or transfer of ownership to successors.
label: BODY

text: At the end of the module, entrepreneurs will:
label: BODY

text: Learn how to change the ownership of a business through selling, closing or passing the business to
label: BODY

text: successors
label: BODY

text: Know how to establish an exit strategy for retirement which includes a succession plan, transferring
label: BODY

text: ownership of the business and paying taxes
label: BODY

text: It may be best for companies in all stages of business development, especially those who plan to sell or transfer
label: BODY

text: ownership to others in the future.
label: BODY

text: Tax Planning
label: BODY

text: The “Tax Planning” module introduces the entrepreneur or participants to tax requirements at the local, state
label: BODY

text: and federal levels and helps them to create a plan to pay their taxes.
label: BODY

text: At the end of the module, entrepreneurs will:
label: BODY

text: Understand the range of state, local and federal tax reporting requirements of a small business and its
label: BODY

text: owner
label: BODY

text: Be able to research general tax reporting requirements
label: BODY

text: Understand the importance of establishing a plan to pay taxes
label: BODY

text: It may best for companies in all stages of business development, especially those who have not yet set up
label: BODY

text: systems and processes for paying taxes in a timely manner.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: Page 11 of 92
label: BODY

text: Time Management
label: BODY

text: The “Time Management” module explains the concept of time management and why it’s important to a small
label: BODY

text: business.
label: BODY

text: At the end of the module, entrepreneurs will:
label: BODY

text: Understand the importance of time management
label: BODY

text: Discover commonly used time management practices like
label: BODY

text: o Pareto analysis
label: BODY

text: o ABC method
label: BODY

text: o Eisenhower method
label: BODY

text: o POSEC method
label: BODY

text: It may be best for companies in all stages of business development as the nature of small businesses is that they
label: BODY

text: are typically short staffed. As such, time management is critical to their success.
label: BODY

text: The Time Management module may work well if combined with the Organization Types module as it fosters
label: BODY

text: thinking about how to fulfill the needs of the business, who is involved and what other human resources are
label: BODY

text: needed.
label: BODY

text: Is Small Business Ownership a Good Fit For You?
label: BODY

text: The “Is Small Business Ownership a Good Fit For You?” module is one of three new modules and helps the
label: BODY

text: aspiring entrepreneur think about the realities of starting a business and their readiness to start a business.
label: BODY

text: At the end of the module, entrepreneurs will:
label: BODY

text: Discern between the myths and realities of small business ownership
label: BODY

text: Start a self-assessment to determine their readiness to become a small business owner
label: BODY

text: Gain insight about their readiness to start a business
label: BODY

text: It may be best for aspiring entrepreneurs at the early stages of their decision-making, but existing business
label: BODY

text: owners can also benefit from the self-assessments in the Participant Guide.
label: BODY

text: It’s also recommended that this module be offered first in a program as it helps set the stage for later modules or
label: BODY

text: classes.
label: BODY

text: Planning for a Healthy Business
label: BODY

text: The “Planning for a Healthy Business” module is the second of the three new modules and introduces aspiring
label: BODY

text: entrepreneurs to the benefits of planning and making smart decisions.
label: BODY

text: It’s recommended that this module be part of the second class in a program as it covers four different forms of
label: BODY

text: planning, from simple to complex.
label: BODY

text: At the end of the module, entrepreneurs will:
label: BODY

text: Discover a 4-Step Business Planning process, via a case study, that will help them create a long-term
label: BODY

text: healthy business
label: BODY

text: o Back-of-Napkin Plan
label: BODY

text: o Resource Plan
label: BODY

text: o Business Plan
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: Page 12 of 92
label: BODY

text: o Action Plan
label: BODY

text: It may be best for aspiring entrepreneurs who are thinking about starting a business. The planning process will
label: BODY

text: elevate their decision-making. Existing business owners can also benefit from some of the planning tools
label: BODY

text: provided in their Participant Guide.
label: BODY

text: Entrepreneurs attending this class will be introduced to business planning, but should seek alternative business
label: BODY

text: planning resources to develop a business plan on their own or with the assistance from the organization hosting
label: BODY

text: the training and/or its partners.
label: BODY

text: Managing Cash Flow
label: BODY

text: The “Managing Cash Flow” module is a great overview of cash flow and how to manage cash flow. This is the
label: BODY

text: third new module and should be scheduled after the Financial Management module.
label: BODY

text: At the end of the module, entrepreneurs will:
label: BODY

text: Learn about the critical importance of cash flow management in a small business
label: BODY

text: Act as advisors to Bob and the Wired Cup
label: BODY

text: Understand the need for expert assistance and advice
label: BODY

text: It may be best for companies in all stages of business development, especially those who lack financial
label: BODY

text: management expertise. This module is especially helpful for new business owners who need to prepare to work
label: BODY

text: with accountants, as it demystifies a lot of cash flow terminology.
label: BODY

text: The Deep Dive
label: HH2

text: The “Managing Cash Flow” module is a highly interactive learning experience that encourages participants to
label: BODY

text: focus on cash flow management as an essential competency of business ownership. No matter where learners
label: BODY

text: are in the development of their businesses, this 90-minute module encourages them to ask questions about their
label: BODY

text: business and prepare to interact with accountants to analyze the flow of cash in and out of their business.
label: BODY

text: On page 27 in the appendix, you will find the Participant Guide for the Managing Cash Flow Module.
label: BODY

text: Evaluation Best Practices
label: H4

text: At the end of every module or class, each module should be evaluated for two main reasons:
label: BODY

text: 1. To evaluate the quality and impact of the module
label: BODY

text: 2. To help identify what is next
label: BODY

text: Evaluate for Quality and Impact
label: BODY

text: The Participant Guide for each module includes an evaluation form on the last page. The forms are easy to
label: BODY

text: complete. Evaluation forms are effective tools for gauging immediate reactions to a class. Another great way to
label: BODY

text: evaluate impact is to conduct an anonymous follow-up survey about a week after the class. Consider using a
label: BODY

text: free online tool to create a survey for the participants.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: Page 13 of 92
label: BODY

text: Ask questions such as:
label: BODY

text: Now that you have had time to reflect, what do you feel were the most compelling learning points of the
label: BODY

text: Managing Cash Flow module?
label: BODY

text: What steps have you taken to apply the Managing Cash Flow module key principles to your own small
label: BODY

text: business?
label: BODY

text: If you have not applied the principles of Managing Cash Flow to your small business, what prevented
label: BODY

text: you?
label: BODY

text: Evaluate what is next
label: BODY

text: Here are some ways to identify which modules your participants will most want/need:
label: BODY

text: At the end of a class, conduct a debriefing conversation. Ask, “What should happen next?”
label: BODY

text: Scan the Parking Lot for questions that indicate a need for additional classes.
label: BODY

text: Interview guest experts for their ideas. They can offer great advice based on the questions the
label: BODY

text: participants asked them.
label: BODY

text: Getting Started With MSSB
label: HH2

text: Selecting Modules
label: BODY

text: When selecting which modules to deliver and in what sequence, please consider the following information:
label: BODY

text: The modules can stand-alone and be presented topic by topic
label: BODY

text: The modules can be mixed and matched to meet the entrepreneur’s needs
label: BODY

text: The modules can be integrated into an existing training program
label: BODY

text: The modules are free of copyrights, which means financial institution and community logos can be
label: BODY

text: added to the materials
label: BODY

text: The modules are available in Word and PDF formats and thus customizable
label: BODY

text: Selection Options
label: BODY

text: Ideally any program will start with the two fundamental modules: Is Small Business Ownership a Good Fit for
label: BODY

text: You? and Planning for a Healthy Business. These modules cover fundamental principles of small business
label: BODY

text: ownership. They are very interactive, which helps host organizations learn more about the entrepreneurs
label: BODY

text: businesses and concerns. Some financial institutions and community organizations offer individual classes once
label: BODY

text: or twice a week for a number of weeks, as shown on the following page. A benefit of this approach is that host
label: BODY

text: Working with Experts
label: BODY

text: Many MSSB Alliance members use guest experts to augment the experience and expertise of the host
label: BODY

text: organization instructor. Guest experts bring a wealth of experience and expertise to Money Smart classes.
label: BODY

text: There are three main categories of experts:
label: BODY

text: 1. Small business owners who have great stories to share (both success stories and cautionary tales)
label: BODY

text: 2. Representatives from such fields as banking, credit reporting and taxation
label: BODY

text: 3. Professionals who advise clients on a regular basis, such as accountants or insurance brokers
label: BODY

text: Guest experts contribute a great deal to Money Smart classes. They tell interesting stories and share real-life
label: BODY

text: experiences about what to do, or not to do. There are some risks associated with working with experts, as well.
label: BODY

text: If they are unprepared they can be ineffective. They can lose track of time or provide examples that are not
label: BODY

text: relevant to the questions the learners ask. Some experts tend to use jargon or technical language which might
label: BODY

text: confuse participants more than help them. When working with experts, provide them with clear directions and
label: BODY

text: parameters to ensure success.
label: BODY

text: Join the Money Smart Alliance
label: BODY

text: Anyone can download the Money Smart for Small Business curriculum which is available at the FDIC Catalog.
label: BODY

text: However, we encourage organizations to join the Money Smart Alliance to benefit from meeting other MSSB
label: BODY

text: users.
label: BODY

text: There is a short form to fill out and the most updated link will always be available at the MSSB Webpage.
label: BODY

text: Both joining the alliance and downloading the curriculums are very easy. The materials available for download
label: BODY

text: are: Instructor Guide, Participant Guide and PowerPoint presentation for each of the modules. A CD-ROM
label: BODY

text: including all modules can also be ordered by using the FDIC Catalog ordering system.
label: BODY

text: Eligibility
label: BODY

text: No certifications are required to use the curriculum; however, it’s ideal that MSSB instructors have experience
label: BODY

text: in the delivery of training, technical assistance or coaching for small businesses. The website (under the heading
label: BODY

text: “Money Smart for Small Business Alliance”) includes a self-assessment questionnaire that should help
label: BODY

text: organizations determine whether they are ready to adopt MSSB. The most current questionnaire is below:
label: BODY

text: Is Your Organization Ready to Offer Training? A Self-Assessment
label: BODY

text: The following questions can help you gauge your organization's readiness to offer Money Smart for Small
label: BODY

text: Business as a member of the Money Smart Alliance. These questions can also help you think about the steps
label: BODY

text: you’ll need to take to set up a training program in your community.
label: BODY

text: Does your organization have experience providing training to small businesses (including technical
label: BODY

text: assistance, mentoring, coaching, etc.)?
label: BODY

text: Does your organization work with small businesses to help them raise debt or equity?
label: BODY

text: Does your organization provide finance directly or in partnership with others?
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: Page 16 of 92
label: BODY

text: Are your organization’s marketing efforts able to reach into the small business community?
label: BODY

text: Are you able to reach unbanked/underbanked populations?
label: BODY

text: Do you have partners to help you in these efforts?
label: BODY

text: Do you have your target market for the training in mind?
label: BODY

text: Does your organization have subject matter experts in-house? If not, do you have access to experts to
label: BODY

text: deliver the course?
label: BODY

text: Is your organization or your partners able to provide follow-up support after the completion of the class?
label: BODY

text: If you’ve answered “Yes” to the majority of these questions, then you’re in good shape to deliver quality
label: BODY

text: trainings!

text: Checking In
label: H4

text: Welcome to Managing Cash Flow. By taking this training, you are taking an
label: BODY

text: important step toward successful small business ownership. As a small business
label: BODY

text: owner, it is important to know how much cash is moving in and out of your
label: BODY

text: business. You need to think ahead in order to meet financial obligations and
label: BODY

text: run a profitable business on a long-term basis.
label: BODY

text: This class introduces some basic cash flow concepts that can get you started.
label: BODY

text: Learning Objectives
label: HH3

text: After completing this module, you will be able to:
label: BODY

text: • Describe the purpose of cash flow management in a start-up small business.
label: BODY

text: • Assess a cash flow cycle and make some cash flow projections.
label: BODY

text: • Describe how a cash flow statement can help assess and improve the financial health of a start-up.
label: BODY

text: • Identify some ways to manage cash flow in terms of managing costs and potential income.
label: BODY

text: • Identify ways to seek out expert technical assistance to improve cash flow management.
label: BODY

text: Introducing Bob and the Wired Cup
label: H4

text: Bob recently opened a new bakery café, The Wired Cup. The café has
label: BODY

text: a great location in a small college town. To get started, Bob invested
label: BODY

text: $30,000 of his own money and received a $20,000 loan from a
label: BODY

text: commercial bank. He spent $45,000 on start-up costs, leaving $5,000
label: BODY

text: to run his business.
label: BODY

text: The Wired Cup is already popular with students, university staff, and
label: BODY

text: neighbors. Everyone loves the coffee and baked goods. A college
label: BODY

text: dean has started to order croissants for the faculty dining hall. Bob is
label: BODY

text: building a great new business.
label: BODY

text: However, Bob has concerns. He has not yet paid himself, and he
label: BODY

text: wonders when he can. The $5,000 is almost gone. Given that his key
label: BODY

text: customers are students, he assumes many of them will go home over
label: BODY

text: holiday breaks and the summer. Questions Bob is now asking:
label: BODY

text: • How will he pay his bills if there are fewer customers?
label: BODY

text: • Will he have enough money to ramp up again in September?
label: BODY

text: • Should he buy in bulk to reduce costs?
label: BODY

text: • Will suppliers allow Bob to buy on credit, or does he still have to pay cash?
label: BODY

text: The good news is that Bob is thinking ahead. He has time to work to find some solutions. As we review The
label: BODY

text: Wired Cup’s cash flow issues, you will be able to apply these concepts to your own business.
label: BODY

text: Cash Conversion Cycle
label: H4

text: A cash conversion cycle depicts how business dollars are invested in raw materials, resources, and
label: BODY

text: other inputs. Those raw materials can be converted into products that are sold to generate payments
label: BODY

text: or cash.
label: BODY

text: If you have a short conversion cycle, you can quickly sell inventory or turn it back into cash which
label: BODY

text: puts money back into the cash flow system in a relatively short period of time.
label: BODY

text: If you have a long cash conversion cycle, you will not be able to use that money while your inventory is
label: BODY

text: unsold, sitting on your shelves. Money will not be flowing back into the system.
label: BODY

text: Notes
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Cash Flow Diagram Descriptions
label: BODY

text: The cash flow diagram on the previous page contains several key cash flow elements. It is a
label: BODY

text: representation of how cash moves in and out of the system, and many of the key decision points or
label: BODY

text: valves a business owner can control.
label: BODY

text: When you start a business, money flows into the business via debt or equity.
label: BODY

text: The valves in the diagram represent decision points. Your decisions impact cash flow and
label: BODY

text: increase or decrease your probability of success. Some valves are open all the time (like taxes and
label: BODY

text: debt). They are a constant drain on your cash which is why they are on the bottom. Some valves are
label: BODY

text: partially open, like the sales, general, and administrative valves. You always spend money here; how
label: BODY

text: much is up to you. As you spend available cash, balance in the center tank drops.
label: BODY

text: Inventory. You spend money on raw materials, labor, and other direct costs to produce a product to
label: BODY

text: sell (assuming you are producing a product, but the same principles apply for services as well). If you
label: BODY

text: decide to spend a lot on inventory, you are deciding to tie up your money until you sell the inventory
label: BODY

text: and turn it into cash. This is called the cash conversion cycle.
label: BODY

text: Fixed assets are usually expensive items that last, such as buildings, upgrades to space, vehicles,
label: BODY

text: equipment, computers, and technology. If you purchase an expensive fixed asset, it ties up available
label: BODY

text: cash. A better option is to lease to keep cash flowing.
label: BODY

text: Profit generator (sales pump). In the top left corner is a sales pump. Keep this primed to pump
label: BODY

text: sales back into the system.
label: BODY

text: Accounts receivable (A/R). You may make a sale, but not the cash until you collect it. Ultimately
label: BODY

text: you want to convert your accounts receivable into cash, so it flows into the center tank and becomes
label: BODY

text: available cash
label: BODY

text: Accounts payable (A/P). In the center tank, accounts payable are represented by bricks. This is
label: BODY

text: money owed to vendors and suppliers who extend credit to you. For example, you receive a product or
label: BODY

text: service but you have not yet paid for it. You still have use of that money. The bricks elevate the water.
label: BODY

text: Instead of having to pay for a product or service, you can use that money for marketing or paying
label: BODY

text: another bill.
label: BODY

text: Balancing accounts payable and accounts receivable is challenging.  You want customers to pay you as
label: BODY

text: quickly as possible (cash in) and you want to pay as slowly as possible (cash out). Your vendors are
label: BODY

text: doing the same thing. They want you to pay quickly, and they may be slow to pay their own vendors.
label: BODY

text: Ultimately, you want to have and be generating excess cash flow from profitable operations
label: BODY

text: (ECFPO). This is the showerhead, which represents your paycheck.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: MANAGING CASH FLOW PARTICIPANT GUIDE
label: BODY

text: Page 34 of 92
label: BODY

text: Cash Flow Statements
label: H4

text: A cash flow statement tells a story:
label: BODY

text: 1. How much money you have to run your business.
label: BODY

text: 2. How much cash is moving in and out of the business.
label: BODY

text: 3. Where that cash is coming from and going to.
label: BODY

text: 4. When the cash is moving or needs to move.
label: BODY

text: As a business owner, you need to think ahead in order to meet your financial obligations and run a
label: BODY

text: profitable business. A cash flow statement helps identify when your business is generating more cash
label: BODY

text: than you need to meet obligations. Conversely, it tells you when the business is running short. Cash
label: BODY

text: flow statements help you make smart, timely decisions that ensure your business is financially healthy
label: BODY

text: over the long term.
label: BODY

text: A cash flow statement for The Wired Cup is on the next page.
label: BODY

text: Notes
label: BODY

text: Note:  The payroll taxes rate used in this example is 15%.  You will need to determine the appropriate local, state, and applicable federal taxes.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: MANAGING CASH FLOW PARTICIPANT GUIDE
label: BODY

text: Page 36 of 92
label: BODY

text: What Can Bob Do?
label: H4

text: To stay in business, Bob needs to increase his sales revenue. He also needs to
label: BODY

text: negotiate agreements that decrease costs and help to control cash flow. To do
label: BODY

text: this, he needs to juggle some competing demands. He wants to hold on to his
label: BODY

text: cash as long as possible. His landlord and vendors want to be paid right away.
label: BODY

text: To balance these expectations, Bob needs to make agreements that benefit all
label: BODY

text: involved parties. These “win–win” negotiations benefit all parties. Bob has lots
label: BODY

text: of opportunities to negotiate win–win agreements.
label: BODY

text: If you were advising him, what would you suggest?
label: BODY

text: • How can Bob increase sales revenue at The Wired Cup?
label: BODY

text: • How could Bob negotiate a better deal or two with his vendors and suppliers?
label: BODY

text: • How can Bob plan for the seasonal ups and downs in his business?
label: BODY

text: • Is it wise for Bob to use a credit card to offset cash flow issues?
label: BODY

text: Notes
label: BODY

text: What NOT To Do
label: BODY

text: Do not postpone paying estimated taxes.
label: BODY

text: Do not hide from loan officers – they can provide invaluable advice.
label: BODY

text: Do not pay vendors later (they can cut off supply).
label: BODY

text: Do not overestimate revenue.
label: BODY

text: Do not underestimate costs.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: MANAGING CASH FLOW PARTICIPANT GUIDE
label: BODY

text: Page 37 of 92
label: BODY

text: Negotiating Better Terms
label: BODY

text: To manage cash flow, you want your customers to pay you right away so
label: BODY

text: you can use that cash to meet your financial obligations. On the other
label: BODY

text: hand, you want to pay your vendors as late as possible, usually 30 days.
label: BODY

text: The trick is to manage your accounts receivable (the money others owe
label: BODY

text: you) and your accounts payable (the money you owe).
label: BODY

text: Customers
label: BODY

text: • If a customer pays cash, this is great. If a customer pays with a credit or debit card, this is good, but the
label: BODY

text: profitability is lower because the business has to pay a credit card processing service and fees charged by the
label: BODY

text: credit card issuer. These fees are usually not negotiable. Ask customers to pay in cash to avoid fees. Some
label: BODY

text: small companies no longer take credit or debit cards; the risk is that some customers might not buy if they do
label: BODY

text: not have cash on them.
label: BODY

text: • Sell gift cards. The buyer of a gift card pays you the full amount of the gift card up front.
label: BODY

text: • Corporate accounts are a great way to increase sales. The challenge is that these customers do not always pay
label: BODY

text: right away. Most invoices are supposed to be paid in 30 days. That creates lag time between when the product
label: BODY

text: or service is provided, and when a business is paid. Most invoices are “net 30 days,” which means the client
label: BODY

text: pays within 30 days of the date the product or service is delivered. To improve cash flow and to get paid
label: BODY

text: early, a business owner can ask a corporate account to pay when the invoice is received, or maybe in 10 or 15
label: BODY

text: days. Offer them incentives to pay early. Most businesses offer a “2/10, net 30” discount meaning the
label: BODY

text: customer will receive a 2% invoice discount if they pay in 10 days instead of 30.
label: BODY

text: Vendors and Suppliers
label: BODY

text: • Most new businesses are required by their vendors to pay cash for supplies, inventory, and the like. After you
label: BODY

text: develop a good reputation for paying on time (maybe a year), ask vendors to invoice you instead of asking for
label: BODY

text: cash. This allows a business to pay in 30 days, which preserves cash flow.
label: BODY

text: Landlords
label: BODY

text: A major fixed monthly expense for many business owners is a lease or rent payment. Before you agree
label: BODY

text: to a lease and the subsequent fixed monthly cost, you may be able to negotiate better terms and
label: BODY

text: payment options to free up your cash flow. Carefully review the lease conditions and negotiate any
label: BODY

text: added expenses or fees associated with the lease, such as upkeep, maintenance, common areas,
label: BODY

text: utilities, snow removal, landscaping services, or parking lot maintenance. As part of the negotiation you
label: BODY

text: can discuss options, such as sub-leases, exclusivity, and co-tenancy.
label: BODY

text: Think about what happens if you default. What would happen to your business? You may be able to
label: BODY

text: negotiate those terms as well. A lawyer could provide you advice.
label: BODY

text: If you know that your business is seasonal, negotiate a payment plan. Let’s say your rent is $1,000 per
label: BODY

text: month. If you anticipate your revenue to go down because of seasonal issues, ask the landlord to accept
label: BODY

text: early or late payments. Another idea might be to make fewer payments. For instance, multiplying the
label: BODY

text: $1,000 by 12 months equals $12,000. Divide $12,000 by nine, which comes to $1,333 per month. You
label: BODY

text: pay the same $12,000 to the landlord but you do not have to pay during the three months when you
label: BODY

text: expect your revenue to be down.

text: Glossary of Cash Flow Terms
label: BODY

text: Term
label: BODY

text: Definition
label: BODY

text: Accounts Payable
label: BODY

text: Accounts payable (A/P) is money a business owner owes to vendors, service
label: BODY

text: providers, tax agencies and so on. Liability that results from the purchase of
label: BODY

text: goods or services (money owed to others).
label: BODY

text: Accounts Receivable
label: BODY

text: Accounts receivable (A/R) is money that is due from customers as a result of
label: BODY

text: delivering goods or services and extending credit in the ordinary course of
label: BODY

text: business.
label: BODY

text: Accrual Basis of
label: BODY

text: Accounting
label: BODY

text: The accrual basis of accounting measures the performance and position of a
label: BODY

text: company by recognizing economic events regardless of when cash
label: BODY

text: transactions occur. The general idea is that economic events are recognized
label: BODY

text: by matching revenues to expenses (the matching principle) at the time in
label: BODY

text: which the transaction occurs rather than when payment is made (or
label: BODY

text: received). This method allows the current cash inflows/outflows to be
label: BODY

text: combined with future expected cash inflows/outflows to give a more
label: BODY

text: accurate picture of a company's current financial condition.
label: BODY

text: Fixed Assets
label: BODY

text: A fixed asset is a long-term tangible piece of property that a firm owns and
label: BODY

text: uses in the production of its income and is not expected to be consumed or
label: BODY

text: converted into cash any sooner than at least one year's time.
label: BODY

text: Balance Sheet
label: BODY

text: A balance sheet is a financial statement that summarizes a company's assets,
label: BODY

text: liabilities and shareholders' equity at a specific point in time. These three
label: BODY

text: balance sheet segments give investors an idea as to what the company owns
label: BODY

text: and owes, as well as the amount invested by the shareholders.
label: BODY

text: Burn Rate
label: BODY

text: A burn rate describes the rate at which a new company uses up its venture
label: BODY

text: capital to finance overhead before generating positive cash flow from
label: BODY

text: operations. In other words, it's a measure of negative cash flow.
label: BODY

text: Capital
label: BODY

text: Capital can mean many things. Its specific definition depends on the context
label: BODY

text: in which it is used. In general, it refers to financial resources available for
label: BODY

text: use such as: financial assets or the financial value of assets, such as cash. It
label: BODY

text: is also used to describe the factories, machinery, and equipment owned by a
label: BODY

text: business and used in production.
label: BODY

text: Cash Conversion Cycle
label: BODY

text: A cash conversion cycle depicts how business dollars are invested in
label: BODY

text: materials, resources, and other inputs. Raw materials can be converted into
label: BODY

text: products that are sold to generate payments or cash. If a business has a short
label: BODY

text: conversion cycle, the owner can quickly turn it back into cash which puts
label: BODY

text: money back into the business in a relatively short period of time. If a
label: BODY

text: business has a long cash conversion cycle, the owner will not be able to use
label: BODY

text: that money while inventory is unsold.
label: BODY

text: Cash Flow Statement
label: BODY

text: A cash flow statement tells a business how much money is available to run
label: BODY

text: the business, how much cash is moving in and out of the business, where
label: BODY

text: that cash is coming from and going to, and when the cash is moving or needs
label: BODY

text: to move.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: MANAGING CASH FLOW PARTICIPANT GUIDE
label: BODY

text: Page 39 of 92
label: BODY

text: Term
label: BODY

text: Definition
label: BODY

text: A cash flow statement helps a business owner to think ahead. It helps
label: BODY

text: pinpoint when a business is generating more cash than needed to meet
label: BODY

text: obligations. Conversely, it alerts a business owner when the business is
label: BODY

text: running short. Cash flow statements are invaluable tools that permit business
label: BODY

text: owners to make smart, timely decisions over the long term.
label: BODY

text: Cash on Hand
label: BODY

text: Funds that are immediately available to a business, and can be spent as
label: BODY

text: needed.
label: BODY

text: Current Assets
label: BODY

text: A balance sheet account that represents the value of all assets that are
label: BODY

text: reasonably expected to be converted into cash within one year in the normal
label: BODY

text: course of business. Current assets include cash, accounts receivable,
label: BODY

text: inventory, marketable securities, prepaid expenses and other liquid assets
label: BODY

text: that can be readily converted to cash.
label: BODY

text: Current Liabilities
label: BODY

text: A company's debts or obligations that are due within one year. Current
label: BODY

text: liabilities appear on the company's balance sheet and include short term
label: BODY

text: debt, accounts payable, accrued liabilities and other debts
label: BODY

text: Debt Principal
label: BODY

text: Amount borrowed or the amount still owed on a loan, separate from interest
label: BODY

text: Depreciation
label: BODY

text: Income tax deduction that allows a taxpayer to recover the cost or other
label: BODY

text: basis of certain property; annual allowance for the wear and tear,
label: BODY

text: deterioration, or obsolescence of the property.
label: BODY

text: Equity
label: BODY

text: Equity is a stock or any other security representing an ownership interest.
label: BODY

text: On a company's balance sheet, equity is the amount of the funds contributed
label: BODY

text: by the owners (the stockholders) plus the retained earnings or losses.
label: BODY

text: Fixed Cost
label: BODY

text: A fixed cost does not change with an increase or decrease in the amount of
label: BODY

text: goods or services produced. Fixed costs are expenses that have to be paid by
label: BODY

text: a company, independent of any business activity. It is one of the two
label: BODY

text: components of the total cost of a good or service, along with variable cost.
label: BODY

text: Gross Profit
label: BODY

text: Gross Profit is a company's revenue minus its cost of goods sold. It is a
label: BODY

text: company's residual profit after selling a product or service and deducting the
label: BODY

text: cost associated with its production and sale.
label: BODY

text: Income Statement
label: BODY

text: A financial statement that measures a company's financial performance over
label: BODY

text: a specific accounting period. Financial performance is assessed by giving a
label: BODY

text: summary of how the business incurs its revenues and expenses through both
label: BODY

text: operating and non-operating activities. It shows the net profit or loss
label: BODY

text: incurred over a specific period, typically over a fiscal quarter or year. An
label: BODY

text: Income Statement is also known as a profit and loss statement or statement
label: BODY

text: of revenue and expense.
label: BODY

text: Interest
label: BODY

text: Interest is a fee paid for the use of another party's money. To the borrower it
label: BODY

text: is the cost of renting money, to the lender the income from lending it.
label: BODY

text: Invoice
label: BODY

text: An invoice is a commercial document that itemizes a transaction between a
label: BODY

text: buyer and a seller. It will usually include the quantity of purchase, price of
label: BODY

text: goods and/or services, date, parties involved, unique invoice number, and
label: BODY

text: tax information. If goods or services were purchased on credit, the invoice
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: MANAGING CASH FLOW PARTICIPANT GUIDE
label: BODY

text: Page 40 of 92
label: BODY

text: Term
label: BODY

text: Definition
label: BODY

text: will usually specify the terms of the deal and provide information on the
label: BODY

text: available methods of payment. An invoice is also known as a bill, statement,
label: BODY

text: or sales invoice.
label: BODY

text: Liquidity
label: BODY

text: Liquidity is the degree to which an asset or security can be bought or sold in
label: BODY

text: the market without affecting the asset's price. Liquidity is characterized by a
label: BODY

text: high level of trading activity. Assets that can be easily bought or sold are
label: BODY

text: known as liquid assets. The term is also used to define the ability to convert
label: BODY

text: an asset to cash quickly. Also known as marketability. Liquidity is often
label: BODY

text: calculated by using liquidity ratios.
label: BODY

text: Net Profit
label: BODY

text: Net Profit is your bottom line. This shows how much your company is
label: BODY

text: making on sales after expenses, interest, and taxes.
label: BODY

text: Variable Cost
label: BODY

text: A variable cost is a corporate expense that varies with production output.
label: BODY

text: Variable costs fluctuate depending on a company's production volume. They
label: BODY

text: rise as production increases and fall as production decreases. Variable costs
label: BODY

text: differ from fixed costs such as rent, advertising, insurance and office
label: BODY

text: supplies, which tend to remain the same regardless of production output.
label: BODY

text: Fixed costs plus variable costs equal total cost.
label: BODY

text: Vendor
label: BODY

text: A vendor is a party in the supply chain that makes goods and services
label: BODY

text: available to companies or consumers. The term is typically used to describe
label: BODY

text: an entity that is paid for the goods that are provided, rather than the
label: BODY

text: manufacturer of the goods. A vendor, however, can operate both as the
label: BODY

text: supplier of goods (seller) and the manufacturer.
label: BODY

text: Purpose
label: BODY

text: This module—Managing Cash Flow—is a highly interactive learning experience that
label: BODY

text: encourages the participants to focus on cash flow management as an essential competency of
label: BODY

text: business ownership. No matter where learners are in the development of their businesses, this
label: BODY

text: 90-minute module encourages them to ask and answer great questions about their business
label: BODY

text: and to get ready to interact with accountants to analyze the flow of cash in and out of their
label: BODY

text: businesses.
label: BODY

text: This Instructor Guide is the key document for this class. Please read it thoroughly.
label: BODY

text: We provide plenty of white space for you to add notes and examples from your own
label: BODY

text: experience. Please also review the related PowerPoint slides and Participant Guide in detail.
label: BODY

text: These documents contain information or visuals you will reference during the class.
label: BODY

text: Preparing for Class
label: BODY

text: Each participant will require a Participant Guide (ideally printed two-sided). Participants do
label: BODY

text: not need copies of the slides. Before printing the participant guides, consider adding local
label: BODY

text: information to the For More Information section. In the space provided, list local resources
label: BODY

text: that offer technical assistance or financing options to small businesses.
label: BODY

text: Objectives
label: BODY

text: After completing this training, the participants will be able to:
label: BODY

text: • Describe the purpose of cash flow management in a start-up small business.
label: BODY

text: • Assess a cash flow cycle and make some cash flow projections.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: MANAGING CASH FLOW INSTRUCTOR GUIDE
label: BODY

text: Page 51 of 92
label: BODY

text: • Describe how a cash flow statement can help assess and improve the financial health of a
label: BODY

text: start-up.
label: BODY

text: • Identify some ways to manage cash flow in terms of managing costs and potential income.
label: BODY

text: • Identify ways to seek out expert technical assistance to improve cash flow management.
label: BODY

text: Presentation Time
label: BODY

text: To ensure high engagement levels with your learners, allow at least 90 minutes to deliver this
label: BODY

text: class. Use the suggested times to personalize the class based on the needs of your participants
label: BODY

text: and the given time. Allow extra time for discussion and questions when teaching larger
label: BODY

text: groups.
label: BODY

text: Materials and Equipment
label: BODY

text: You will need the following materials and equipment to present this class:
label: BODY

text: • Instructor Guide (for your use only).
label: BODY

text: • Participant Guide – ideally printed two-sided – for each participant. As noted above, you may add
label: BODY

text: local resources to the For More Information section of the Participant Guide.
label: BODY

text: • PowerPoint slides (for your use only).
label: BODY

text: • Audiovisual equipment such as a computer, Microsoft Office PowerPoint, overhead projector, and
label: BODY

text: microphone, if appropriate.
label: BODY

text: • Optional: flipchart easel, chart paper, markers.
label: BODY

text: Discussion Points
label: BODY

text: • Managing cash flow is a core competency of small business ownership.
label: BODY

text: • A balance sheet tells a compelling story.
label: BODY

text: • A cash flow statement continues that story. Use it to monitor projected and actual income
label: BODY

text: and expenses.
label: BODY

text: • Plan for seasonal fluctuations.
label: BODY

text: • Try to maintain a rapid cash conversion cycle.
label: BODY

text: • Manage your paperwork like a pro.
label: BODY

text: • Ask an accountant for advice.
label: BODY

text: Opening Balance Sheet for The Wired Cup, Cont.
label: BODY

text: This opening balance sheet tells a story: how much money Bob
label: BODY

text: had to start his business, how he financed it, what he did with that
label: BODY

text: money, and how much was left over to run the business.
label: BODY

text: The balance sheet tells us that Bob invested $30,000 of his own
label: BODY

text: money or owner’s equity, and he borrowed $20,000. The $20,000
label: BODY

text: loan is over five years, with an 14.54% interest rate. In year one,
label: BODY

text: Bob will pay back $3,371 of principal and will pay the remaining
label: BODY

text: balance of $16,629 in years two through five.
label: BODY

text: If you do not have the necessary capital to start your business, you
label: BODY

text: have two options to get the capital that you need:
label: BODY

text: • Equity. Friends, family and/or business partners invest in your
label: BODY

text: business. They provide you with cash; you give them equity or
label: BODY

text: a piece of the business.
label: BODY

text: • Debt. You borrow the money from family, friends, or a lending
label: BODY

text: institution, such as a bank. You do not give up equity or
label: BODY

text: ownership but you do have to pay back the loan. You will pay
label: BODY

text: back both principal and interest. There are many types of
label: BODY

text: lending or borrowing options.
label: BODY

text: Slide 9
label: BODY

text: A Few Notes About Debt
label: BODY

text: It takes some effort to obtain a small business loan. As part
label: BODY

text: of the process you will need to provide a business plan. The
label: BODY

text: Money Smart for Small Business module, Planning for a
label: BODY

text: Healthy Business provides a lot of information about various
label: BODY

text: ways to plan a successful business.
label: BODY

text: Know your credit score. The higher your score the lower the
label: BODY

text: risk for creditors. For more information, attend the Money
label: BODY

text: Smart module on Credit Reporting.
label: BODY

text: Banks have differing criteria for lending. Talk with your local
label: BODY

text: bankers before you need a loan. The stronger your
label: BODY

text: relationship, the more supportive they will be to help you
label: BODY

text: secure a loan if you meet their lending criteria. The Money
label: BODY

text: Smart module on Banking Services can help. Be prepared to
label: BODY

text: personally sign for the loan. If a business is unable to meet
label: BODY

text: its financial obligations, you will be held responsible. Also be
label: BODY

text: prepared to pledge collateral.
label: BODY

text: One last note: manage your credit cards to avoid high fees
label: BODY

text: and interest. Business credit cards may be one of the most
label: BODY

text: expensive forms of business credit.
label: BODY

text: Three Views of Cash Flow
label: BODY

text: Let’s look at three views of cash flow: a cash conversion
label: BODY

text: cycle, a cash flow diagram, and The Wired Cup’s cash flow
label: BODY

text: statement.
label: BODY

text: Combined together, these three views provide a
label: BODY

text: comprehensive overview of a cash flow system.

text: Slide 12
label: BODY

text: Slide 13
label: BODY

text: The Cash Conversion Cycle
label: BODY

text: A cash conversion cycle consists of three components:
label: BODY

text: 1. A business pays for raw materials.
label: BODY

text: 2. The business makes a product or service using those
label: BODY

text: materials.
label: BODY

text: 3. The business sells products or services.
label: BODY

text: The trick is to know how long it will take to complete the
label: BODY

text: cycle. That rate of conversion impacts cash flow.
label: BODY

text: If you have a short cycle, you sell inventory or turn it back
label: BODY

text: into cash quickly, which puts money back into the cash flow

text: Cash Flow Diagram Descriptions
label: BODY

text: This diagram is a representation of how cash flows in and out
label: BODY

text: of the system. It depicts many decision points or valves you
label: BODY

text: control.
label: BODY

text: When you start a business, money flows into the business via
label: BODY

text: debt or equity. In the case of The Wired Cup, Bob had
label: BODY

text: $30,000 of his own money invested in the business, the
label: BODY

text: equity bucket in this diagram. In addition, Bob borrowed
label: BODY

text: $20,000, the debt bucket. The combined $50,000 is the
label: BODY

text: available cash working capital.
label: BODY

text: The valves in this cash flow diagram represent decision
label: BODY

text: points. Your decisions impact cash flow and increase or
label: BODY

text: decrease your probability of success.
label: BODY

text: Some valves are open all the time such as sales taxes and
label: BODY

text: debt. You have to pay them. They are a constant drain on
label: BODY

text: your cash, which is why they are on the bottom.
label: BODY

text: Some valves are partially open, like the sales, general, and
label: BODY

text: administrative valves. What you spend is up to you. As you
label: BODY

text: spend available cash, the balance in the center tank drops.
label: BODY

text: Inventory. You spend money on raw materials, labor, and
label: BODY

text: other direct costs to produce a product to sell -- assuming
label: BODY

text: you are producing a product; the same principles apply for
label: BODY

text: services as well. If you spend a lot on inventory you tie up
label: BODY

text: your money until you sell the inventory, and turn it into cash.
label: BODY

text: Fixed assets are usually expensive: buildings, upgrades to
label: BODY

text: space, vehicles, equipment, computers, and technology. If
label: BODY

text: you purchase an expensive fixed asset, it ties up cash. A
label: BODY

text: better option may be to lease to keep cash flowing.
label: BODY

text: Profit generator (sales pump). In the top left corner, we
label: BODY

text: have a sales pump. Keep this primed to pump sales back into
label: BODY

text: the system.
label: BODY

text: Accounts receivable (A/R). You may make a sale, but not
label: BODY

text: receive the cash until you collect it. Ultimately you want to
label: BODY

text: convert A/R into cash, so it flows into the center tank and
label: BODY

text: becomes available. Some A/R will not be paid; this is called
label: BODY

text: bad debt. Usually after 90 days, an A/R will not be paid.
label: BODY

text: When you extend credit and create an A/R, you need to
label: BODY

text: follow up to ensure you receive the payment.
label: BODY

text: Accounts payable (A/P). In the center tank, accounts
label: BODY

text: payable are represented by bricks. This is money owed to
label: BODY

text: vendors and suppliers who extend credit to you. For
label: BODY

text: example, you receive a product or service but you have not
label: BODY

text: yet paid for it. You still have use of that money. The bricks
label: BODY

text: elevate the water. Instead of having to pay for a product or
label: BODY

text: service, you can use that money for marketing or paying
label: BODY

text: A copy of the cash flow
label: BODY

text: begin on page 19 of this guide.
label: BODY

text: another bill.
label: BODY

text: It is challenging to balance accounts payable and accounts
label: BODY

text: receivable. You want customers to pay you as quickly as
label: BODY

text: possible (cash in) and you want to pay your vendors as slowly
label: BODY

text: as possible (cash out).
label: BODY

text: Ultimately, you want to have and be generating excess cash
label: BODY

text: flow from profitable operations or ECFPO. The
label: BODY

text: showerhead represents your paycheck.
label: BODY

text: The broken pipe represents how depreciation can be used to
label: BODY

text: reduce your taxable income. We won’t get into this in this
label: BODY

text: class for time management issues. This is a good question to
label: BODY

text: share with an accountant.
label: BODY

text: This diagram represents a cash flow system and decision
label: BODY

text: points you control. Of course, in business we would not use a
label: BODY

text: diagram. We use a statement which tells a story with
label: BODY

text: numbers.

text: The Cash Flow Statement, cont.
label: BODY

text: The cash flow statement is a valuable decision making tool
label: BODY

text: for business owners, investors, and creditors. It allows
label: BODY

text: everyone to make smart, informed decisions about your
label: BODY

text: business.
label: BODY

text: In this example, Bob made projections based on two months
label: BODY

text: of actual experience in August and September. He does not
label: BODY

text: know how much seasonality --summer vacations at the
label: BODY

text: college-- will affect business. He assumes the impact will be
label: BODY

text: significant.
label: BODY

text: The first column lists money in categories such as loan
label: BODY

text: receipts, owner’s capital, and so on, and money out such as
label: BODY

text: operating expenses for accounting, accounts payable/debt,
label: BODY

text: advertising, and so on.
label: BODY

text: The second column represents Bob’s opening balance sheet
label: BODY

text: start-up costs. You would not typically see this on a cash
label: BODY

text: flow statement. We include this information to demonstrate
label: BODY

text: how elements of an opening balance sheet transfer over to
label: BODY

text: the cash flow statement.
label: BODY

text: The rest of the columns represent monthly income and
label: BODY

text: expenses. As mentioned before, Bob has had two months of
label: BODY

text: actual expenses. Based on what he knows so far, he projected
label: BODY

text: income and expenses for the rest of the year.
label: BODY

text: Notice that Bob had $5,000 in available cash. His sales were
label: BODY

text: $25,000, and sales tax was $1,563.
label: BODY

text: • A note about sales tax. Put this in a separate bank
label: BODY

text: account. Do not co-mingle tax money in your regular
label: BODY

text: bank account. You are collecting tax on behalf of the
label: BODY

text: government. This is not your money to use. Most likely,
label: BODY

text: you will be required to pay this quarterly or even
label: BODY

text: monthly to the government. The payroll taxes rate used
label: BODY

text: in this example is 15%.  You will need to determine the
label: BODY

text: appropriate local, state, and applicable federal taxes.
label: BODY

text: In August, The Wired Cup had a total inflow of cash: $26,563
label: BODY

text: ($25,000 of sales revenue plus $1,563 of sales tax). That
label: BODY

text: means that at the end of August, Bob’s total available cash
label: BODY

text: If we look at the bottom of the spreadsheet for August we see
label: BODY

text: that $29,253 was the cash out flow for the month.
label: BODY

text: • Some cash outflows are fixed month to month, such as Bob’s
label: BODY

text: lease payment of $1,350 and the cable/Internet payment of
label: BODY

text: • Some cash outflows are variable, such as advertising and
label: BODY

text: utilities. Variable amounts fluctuate from month to month.
label: BODY

text: You have some control over how cash flows in and out of
label: BODY

text: your business. For example, for sales you decide what you
label: BODY

text: will sell, where, to whom, how, and at what price. The same
label: BODY

text: goes for expenses. You can decide what space to lease, how
label: BODY

text: much debt to carry, when to advertise, when and how much
label: BODY

text: raw materials to purchase, and how many staff to employ.
label: BODY

text: In August, Bob has available cash of $31,563 and cash
label: BODY

text: account at the end of August. This $2,309 becomes the
label: BODY

text: beginning balance for the month of September, and the
label: BODY

text: process starts all over again.
label: BODY

text: • In September: $2,309 + $27,000 + 1,688 = $30,997 available
label: BODY

text: cash for September. Monthly expenses are $29,778. $30,997 -
label: BODY

text: $29,778 = $1,218 cash available at the end of September,
label: BODY

text: which becomes the beginning balance for October.
label: BODY

text: To sum up: Bob is happy. The Wired Cup is doing well, but
label: BODY

text: he is worried about the rest of the year. He projects he will be
label: BODY

text: able to pay all of his financial obligations but he will be
label: BODY

text: cutting it close.
label: BODY

text: Some business owners overestimate revenue and
label: BODY

text: underestimate costs. This means they will at some point have
label: BODY

text: a cash flow crunch and will not have cash available to meet
label: BODY

text: their obligations. To prevent this, consider developing a
label: BODY

text: couple of cash flow statements:
label: BODY

text: • Best case scenario: This would be an ideal situation where all
label: BODY

text: your dreams come true.
label: BODY

text: • Worst case scenario: This would be a much more conservative
label: BODY

text: scenario where you do not get the sales revenue you would
label: BODY

text: hope for and costs are higher.
label: BODY

text: • Most likely: This would be like the Goldilocks story—not too
label: BODY

text: hot, not too cold, but just right. It is the most likely scenario,
label: BODY

text: somewhere between a best and worst case.
label: BODY

text: In this example, Bob created a most likely projection. Given
label: BODY

text: that he knows the students and faculty leave for vacation, in
label: BODY

text: July he projects a negative $4,316.
label: BODY

text: You can’t have a negative cash situation! Negative cash
label: BODY

text: means game over.
label: BODY

text: What you want to achieve is excess cash flow from profitable
label: BODY

text: operations. This is when you can shower yourself with some
label: BODY

text: cash.

text: What NOT to Do
label: BODY

text: Never use your sales tax as a financing option. Some business
label: BODY

text: owners use sales tax in a cash crunch hoping they replace the
label: BODY

text: tax when things look up. This is a risky bet. Penalties are
label: BODY

text: high for not paying taxes on time.
label: BODY

text: If you anticipate that you might miss or be late on a loan
label: BODY

text: payment, talk to your loan officer as soon as you know. Loan
label: BODY

text: officers understand cash flow and typical business
label: BODY

text: challenges. It is in their interest to help. They don’t want to
label: BODY

text: see you fail. They make money when you are successful and
label: BODY

text: pay back the principal and loan interest.
label: BODY

text: • Do not pay vendors late; they can cut off supply.
label: BODY

text: • Do not overestimate revenue. This is a common mistake
label: BODY

text: many new business owners tend to make.
label: BODY

text: • Do not underestimate costs. Again, this is a common
label: BODY

text: mistake in start-up businesses. Do your homework to find
label: BODY

text: out the real costs of doing business.
label: BODY

text: It Is Professional to Ask for Help
label: BODY

text: It is not a sign of weakness if financial management is new
label: BODY

text: for you.  Find a great accountant or technical advisor at
label: BODY

text: SBDC or SCORE who can explain cash flow in ways that
label: BODY

text: relate the concepts to your own business.
label: BODY

text: An accountant will encourage you to use a computer to
label: BODY

text: manage your cash flow documentation. If you do not already
label: BODY

text: use financial management software, take a course to develop
label: BODY

text: this skill. You also need to manage your paperwork in a
label: BODY

text: professional manner. Set up a reliable filing system to keep
label: BODY

text: track of all financial documents such as tax forms, receipts,
label: BODY

text: invoices, and so on.
label: BODY

text: “Co-opetition”is a real term. Competitors can be good
label: BODY

text: advisors as they cope with the same cash flow issues you do.
label: BODY

text: Find ways to cooperate and share information with them.
label: BODY

text: They have experience to share.
label: BODY

text: Check out the Toolkit of Resources in your Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: for ideas about where to locate technical assistance.

text: Key Points to Remember
label: BODY

text: • Managing cash flow is a core competency of small business
label: BODY

text: ownership.
label: BODY

text: • A balance sheet tells a compelling story. A cash flow statement
label: BODY

text: continues that story. Use it to monitor projected and actual
label: BODY

text: income and expenses.
label: BODY

text: • Plan for seasonal fluctuations. Every business has ups and
label: BODY

text: downs. Ask some of your competitors when their usual slow
label: BODY

text: times tend to occur.
label: BODY

text: • Try to maintain a rapid cash conversion cycle. Try not to tie up
label: BODY

text: too much cash in inventory. Lease equipment instead of buying
label: BODY

text: it. If you do buy equipment, buy used whenever you can.
label: BODY

text: • Manage your paperwork like a pro. Your accountant will
label: BODY

text: expect to see spreadsheets, an accounting program, well-
label: BODY

text: organized receipts, invoices, and financial statements such as
label: BODY

text: banking and credit card statements.
label: BODY

text: • Ask an accountant for advice. Ideally this class has helped you
label: BODY

text: prepare for a series of helpful conversations.
label: BODY

text: What and Why?
label: BODY

text: Money Smart for Small Business (MSSB) is an instructor-led curriculum that
label: BODY

text: provides a practical introduction to key topics related to starting and managing a
label: BODY

text: business. Developed jointly by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation
label: BODY

text: (FDIC) and the U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) in 2012, this free
label: BODY

text: resource has 13 modules, is available for download and in Spanish.   A list of
label: BODY

text: MSSB Alliance members is available at the FDIC website and is updated
label: BODY

text: periodically as a reference for organizations or individuals that want to know
label: BODY

text: who is offering MSSB near them.  There is no cost, and it takes minutes to join
label: BODY

text: the Alliance by completing a short online form. MSSB Alliance members
label: BODY

text: convene on a quarterly basis to share their experiences on MSSB Town Hall
label: BODY

text: conference calls.
label: BODY
