text: Success Tips
label: H4

text: The MSSB Train-the-Trainer instructors/facilitators should have relevant instructor/facilitator skills and
label: BODY

text: experience. The FDIC may conduct orientation workshops to familiarize potential instructors with the
label: BODY

text: curriculum, but neither the FDIC nor SBA certifies trainers to deliver the MSSB curriculum.
label: BODY

text: As an instructor, you are responsible for:
label: BODY

text: • Identifying the learning and communication needs of participants
label: BODY

text: • Focusing and directing participants
label: BODY

text: • Aiming discussions toward course objectives
label: BODY

text: • Making sure every participant has the opportunity to contribute to the discussion
label: BODY

text: You can accomplish these objectives by listening, asking questions, observing participants’ reactions and leading
label: BODY

text: by example.
label: BODY

text: A first step to delivering an effective presentation is to know your audience. You must understand the goals of
label: BODY

text: the course and why the participants need this information. Tips for delivering effective presentations include:
label: BODY

text: • Know your material well. Thoroughly review ALL of the training materials.
label: BODY

text: • Identify potential trouble spots in the exercises, as well as hints for assisting participants.
label: BODY

text: • Practice your presentation.
label: BODY

text: • Use language familiar to the participants, avoiding jargon or unfamiliar terms.
label: BODY

text: • Select and prepare anecdotes from real-world experiences that can be used to illustrate special
label: BODY

text: scenarios, generate discussion and maintain participant interest.
label: BODY

text: • Speak clearly.
label: BODY

text: • Be aware of the tone and pace of how you are speaking.
label: BODY

text: • Avoid going off on tangents and getting off track during a presentation.
label: BODY

text: • Minimize the use of filler words (such as “uh” and “um”).
label: BODY

text: • Make eye contact with participants.
label: BODY

text: • Use natural and positive body language and facial expressions.
label: BODY

text: • Avoid fidgeting, pacing and other nervous habits.
label: BODY

text: • Be yourself.
label: BODY

text: • Make sufficient copies of the Participant Guide and handouts.
label: BODY

text: • If using an LCD projector, make sure beforehand that all computer equipment is functioning and
label: BODY

text: prepare a backup hardcopy of the PowerPoint slides for use during the training.
label: BODY

text: • Give yourself ample time to set up the classroom and distribute participant materials before the
label: BODY

text: training is scheduled to take place.
label: BODY

text: A successful instructor must be able to introduce activities, assign participants to small groups, give instructions
label: BODY

text: and process activity results. When introducing activities, explain the objectives, and emphasize the benefits and
label: BODY

text: potential outcomes of the learning activity. Connect, or link, activities to previously learned concepts and
label: BODY

text: discussions.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: Page 81 of 92
label: BODY

text: Materials and Equipment Needed
label: BODY

text: • Train-the-Trainer Instructor Guide.
label: BODY

text: • Train-the-Trainer Participant Guide. Print one for each participant and one for the trainer to be used
label: BODY

text: as a reference. The Train-the-Trainer participant guide should be printed on two two-sides.
label: BODY

text: • Train-the-Trainer PowerPoint. This should be customized ahead of time, especially if the training
label: BODY

text: includes various sponsoring organizations and/or speakers.
label: BODY

text: • Laptop or computer loaded with the PowerPoint presentation. It isn’t necessary to share the slides
label: BODY

text: with participants. All of the information that’s needed is in their Participant Guides. As a best
label: BODY

text: practice, be prepared for technical issues. Print a few sets of the slides ahead of time and bring a
label: BODY

text: thumb drive with your presentation just in case.
label: BODY

text: • Chart paper and markers for recording responses to key questions and/or to create a Parking Lot for
label: BODY

text: questions you might not be able to answer in class. Chart paper can be created ahead of time.
label: BODY

text: • Slide projector, screen or monitor/TV to display the PowerPoint presentation.
label: BODY

text: • (Optional) Stopwatch or other timer.
label: BODY

text: • (Optional) Painter’s tape for posting chart pages on the wall.
label: BODY

text: • (Optional) Post-it Notes and highlighters that participants can use to flag or highlight key information
label: BODY

text: in their Train-the-Trainer Participant Guides.
label: BODY

text: The Instructor Guide is your roadmap for presenting the Train-the-Trainer workshop. It includes:
label: BODY

text: • The purpose and objectives of the Train-the-Trainer workshop and the curriculum
label: BODY

text: • A detailed lesson plan
label: BODY

text: • Thumbnails of the overhead slides
label: BODY

text: • Additional information that’s not part of the Train-the-Trainer Participant Guide.
label: BODY

text: The lesson plan is laid out in a two-column format. The left-hand column contains the slides used in the
label: BODY

text: presentation. The right-hand column contains a word-for-word script of the module content, as well as more
label: BODY

text: lengthy instructions for delivering the content and conducting the practice exercises.
label: BODY

text: Each module includes a set of visuals to help you present the module content. They are presented in both
label: BODY

text: PowerPoint and PDF formats so you can use them with your specific projection equipment.
label: BODY

text: You should give each student a Participant Guide to use during the training and as a reference when the training
label: BODY

text: is over. It contains:
label: BODY

text: • Important concepts and facts presented in the Train-the-Trainer workshop.
label: BODY

text: • The evaluation form
label: BODY

text: • Space for taking notes
label: BODY

text: • (Optional) Additional ready-to-use resources such as the MSSB Flyer, Agenda, Invitation and
label: BODY

text: Worksheet Templates to be used during Train-the-Trainer workshops
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: Page 82 of 92
label: BODY

text: Giving Instructions
label: BODY

text: The Instructor Guide provides instructions for all the activities in the modules. However, participants may still
label: BODY

text: need clarification. It’s important to speak clearly and slowly when presenting the objectives of an activity and
label: BODY

text: giving instructions. Make sure to define important terms and concepts (refer to the MSSB TtT glossary) and,
label: BODY

text: when possible, demonstrate activities or provide examples for the participants. Also, periodically ask if there are
label: BODY

text: any questions.
label: BODY

text: While students are completing an activity, you should circulate to answer questions and encourage discussion.
label: BODY

text: Keep track of the amount of time allotted for each activity, and inform the students when time is winding down.
label: BODY

text: When processing results, ask questions about how the participants reached their conclusions. Keep the
label: BODY

text: processing from becoming redundant or repetitive by asking the next group to report findings that are different
label: BODY

text: from the previous group’s or by asking each group to present just a part of the solution.
label: BODY

text: When processing individual comments, make sure a diverse group of students is called on to provide responses.
label: BODY

text: Encourage students with different experience levels and perspectives to contribute their observations.
label: BODY

text: Acknowledge correct responses and provide alternative approaches if incomplete or inaccurate responses are
label: BODY

text: given.
label: BODY

text: Facilitating Discussions
label: HH3

text: Interaction among students contributes to a successful learning experience. Varying the composition of small
label: BODY

text: groups for exercises and activities not only energizes students, but also creates more opportunity to exchange
label: BODY

text: information and encounter different perspectives.
label: BODY

text: There are a number of techniques for assigning students to small groups. Common methods include telling
label: BODY

text: students to partner with someone they don’t know or counting off by a specific number and having all the “ones”
label: BODY

text: work together, all the “twos” work together, and so on. Other ways include arbitrarily grouping people who are
label: BODY

text: close to each other or asking students to turn their chairs around to form groups with people at the next table.
label: BODY

text: Informative discussions and exchange of information among instructors and students are other keys to the
label: BODY

text: success of this course. As an instructor, your role is to elicit comments from the students while maintaining the
label: BODY

text: focus of the discussion. The following tips may be useful when you are leading group discussions:
label: BODY

text: • Paraphrase what someone has said so the participant will know he or she has been understood and to
label: BODY

text: ensure the rest of the class hears the comment.
label: BODY

text: • Compliment students on interesting or insightful comments.
label: BODY

text: • Use open-ended questions, because they trigger better discussions than close-ended ones.
label: BODY

text: • Mediate differences of opinions.
label: BODY

text: • Pull ideas together, showing their relationship to one another.
label: BODY

text: • Summarize, and record on chart paper, if appropriate, the major views of the group.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: Page 83 of 92
label: BODY

text: Classroom Set-Up
label: BODY

text: The most effective classroom set-up is to arrange the room into table groups that seat four to six students each.
label: BODY

text: This allows students to complete the small group exercises comfortably. If this arrangement is not possible, you
label: BODY

text: may have to move desks and chairs into small groups to conduct these activities.
label: BODY

text: Using Chart Paper
label: BODY

text: Chart paper lets you capture meaningful information generated by discussion and display it for all students to
label: BODY

text: see. When using chart paper:
label: BODY

text: • Prepare chart paper in advance.
label: BODY

text: • Prepare titles beforehand if students will provide responses.
label: BODY

text: • Write with large, clear, bold letters, using 20 words per page as your guide.
label: BODY

text: • Use words or short phrases to indicate key ideas.
label: BODY

text: • Check your spelling.
label: BODY

text: • Write, turn to the audience and then talk; don’t talk while writing.
label: BODY

text: • Don’t obstruct students’ view of the chart.
label: BODY

text: • Leave the bottom quarter of the paper blank so all of the content can be seen by those in the back of
label: BODY

text: the room.
label: BODY

text: • Tear off chart paper you want the group to be able to refer to throughout the course, and post it on the
label: BODY

text: walls around the classroom.
label: BODY

text: Using Handouts
label: BODY

text: Like other types of materials, handouts help vary the pace of training sessions by giving students a different
label: BODY

text: focus. Reinforce the connection between handouts and course content by introducing and reviewing them. When
label: BODY

text: using handouts:
label: BODY

text: • Prepare the appropriate number of copies ahead of time.
label: BODY

text: • Make sure your handout is concise and designed for easy reading.
label: BODY

text: • Use colored paper to make locating the handouts easier if they’ll be referred to frequently during the
label: BODY

text: course.
label: BODY

text: • Make sure you distribute handouts to each student before beginning to discuss their content.
label: BODY

text: • Don’t distribute handouts as you are speaking; students will focus on the materials rather than what
label: BODY

text: you are saying.
label: BODY

text: Using Visual Aids
label: BODY

text: These tips for using visual aids will help you to be an effective presenter:
label: BODY

text: • Keep visual aids out of sight until you are ready to use them.
label: BODY

text: • Stand to the side of your visual aid.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: Page 84 of 92
label: BODY

text: • Talk to and face the audience, not the visual aid.
label: BODY

text: • Don’t block your face with the visual aid.
label: BODY

text: • Maintain eye contact with your audience.
label: BODY

text: • Make sure your audience has the time to fully read and understand the visual aid before removing it
label: BODY

text: and moving to the next one.
label: BODY

text: • Know where the visual aid goes when you’re finished using it.
label: BODY

text: • Switch the projector off when not in use; its noise and light can be distracting.
label: BODY

text: It’s helpful to practice using visual aids before delivering the actual presentation. All visual aids should be free
label: BODY

text: of grammatical errors and clutter. When presenting visual aids, describe the content and add a few anecdotes or
label: BODY

text: meaningful details. Visual aids should not be read verbatim.
label: BODY

text: Consider the Three Learning Styles While Teaching
label: BODY

text: Experts know that most people learn best in one of three ways:
label: BODY

text: • Visual: Those who learn best by seeing how things are done.
label: BODY

text: • Use visual aids, such as handouts, slides, written instructions, charts and demonstrations.
label: BODY

text: • Stand to the side, talk to and face the audience, allow the audience time to fully read and
label: BODY

text: understand.
label: BODY

text: • Prepare charts in advance, using large, clear, bold letters. Write, turn to the audience, and then
label: BODY

text: talk.
label: BODY

text: • Design handouts for easy reading, and use colored paper to make locating handouts easier.
label: BODY

text: • Auditory: Those who learn best by listening or hearing instructions.
label: BODY

text: • They are affective learners, that is, they tend to be more intuitive than rational. Therefore, they
label: BODY

text: have to feel the learning experience.
label: BODY

text: • They like to get involved with others and share ideas and information.
label: BODY

text: • They like thinking out loud about what they are learning.
label: BODY

text: • Use exercises that allow them to share their experiences with each other. Lectures and audio
label: BODY

text: tapes are also useful for auditory learners.
label: BODY

text: • Tactile/Kinesthetic: Those who learn best by doing.
label: BODY

text: • They like to experiment.
label: BODY

text: • They dislike conventional educational approaches.
label: BODY

text: • They get bored with lectures, presentations or anything that doesn’t allow them to be
label: BODY

text: physically active.
label: BODY

text: • They learn best from hands-on training and physically active exercises.
label: BODY

text: Things to Avoid During a Presentation
label: BODY

text: You can lose the interest of students by doing any of the following:
label: BODY

text: • Failing to prepare
label: BODY

text: • Reading verbatim from notes or a script
label: BODY

text: • Teaching without student involvement
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: Page 85 of 92
label: BODY

text: • Diverging from course objectives
label: BODY

text: • Avoiding eye contact
label: BODY

text: • Using confusing visual aids
label: BODY

text: • Behaving in a condescending or superior manner
label: BODY

text: • Using jargon or language that’s either too simple or complex for participants
label: BODY

text: • Lacking empathy for participants’ needs
label: BODY

text: • Using offensive or critical humor
label: BODY

text: • Making promises you can’t deliver
label: BODY

text: Questions for Self-Reflection
label: BODY

text: Here are some potential challenges you may face. How would you deal with them?
label: BODY

text: • You have made promises you cannot deliver
label: BODY

text: • You are asked a question and you do not know the answer
label: BODY

text: • Fewer or more people show up than anticipated
label: BODY

text: • Someone is sleeping
label: BODY

text: • Someone brought a baby who constantly cries
label: BODY

text: • No one responds to your questions
label: BODY

text: • One person monopolizes the discussion
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Accommodating Students with Disabilities
label: H4

text: Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990
label: BODY

text: On July 26, 1990, the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) became law. The law is designed to protect the
label: BODY

text: civil rights of people with disabilities. The ADA prohibits discrimination on the basis of disability by
label: BODY

text: guaranteeing equal opportunity for individuals with disabilities in public accommodations, commercial facilities,
label: BODY

text: employment, transportation, state and local government services, and telecommunications.
label: BODY

text: The ADA is built on the principles of equal opportunity, full participation, independent living and economic self-
label: BODY

text: sufficiency. It reflects the disability community’s determination to participate fully in the life of their community
label: BODY

text: like other citizens and to have choice and control over their own futures. It’s the most comprehensive policy
label: BODY

text: statement ever made in law in the United States about how the nation should address individuals with
label: BODY

text: disabilities.
label: BODY

text: As a civil rights law, the ADA is similar to other civil rights acts that protect individuals from being
label: BODY

text: discriminated against based on arbitrary criteria such as race, color, religion, age, national origin and sex. For
label: BODY

text: other groups with civil rights protection, the problem has generally been discrimination through policies that
label: BODY

text: limit their participation.
label: BODY

text: For people with disabilities, discrimination often also takes the form of inaccessible facilities that make it
label: BODY

text: impossible for them to gain access to or participate in “standard” activities. For example, stairs leading to the
label: BODY

text: only entrance into a building prohibit entry by someone who uses a wheelchair. Similarly, texts and handouts
label: BODY

text: provided only on paper and in standard-size typeface are inaccessible to someone who is blind or has low vision.
label: BODY

text: In these cases, the ADA requires changes to buildings or locations, and modifications to the way products or
label: BODY

text: services are provided.
label: BODY

text: Making the modules useful and understandable for everyone, regardless of whether or not they have a disability,
label: BODY

text: is perhaps the best reason of all for making the courses accessible.
label: BODY

text: Low- and moderate-income individuals, especially those with little or no banking experience, often don’t have
label: BODY

text: the tools necessary to save and manage money. This lack of a basic understanding of how money works in our
label: BODY

text: society may keep them from achieving financial independence. These individuals also include a significant
label: BODY

text: number of persons with lifelong disabilities, as well as older individuals who acquire disabilities as they age.
label: BODY

text: Some may have undiagnosed or hidden learning disabilities.
label: BODY

text: Requests for Accommodations
label: HH3

text: You may want to consider using a registration form with a space where individuals can indicate whether they
label: BODY

text: need any accommodations and, if so, what types of accommodations may be required. You may also want to ask
label: BODY

text: if students require materials in alternate formats.
label: BODY

text: People with disabilities are never required to self-identify as having a disability – even if the disability is
label: BODY

text: obvious. Therefore, the registration form should not ask the individual to specifically identify the type of
label: BODY

text: disability. That information is not necessary for you to know, and asking for it could be viewed as a type of
label: BODY

text: discrimination.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: Page 87 of 92
label: BODY

text: However, providing a space on the registration form to request accommodations is neutral and welcoming. It’s
label: BODY

text: also a good idea for you to ask all of the students for a way to contact them, by phone and by email, so that you
label: BODY

text: can communicate with people individually if you have questions about any part of the registration form. Put the
label: BODY

text: request for contact information in the body of the registration form – not in the place where you ask if
label: BODY

text: accommodations are needed.
label: BODY

text: How to Make Classes Accessible to Students with Disabilities
label: HH3

text: There are many things that both you and the sponsoring agency can do to make the modules accessible to people
label: BODY

text: with a wide range of disabilities. An overview of actions that can be taken to ensure accessibility follows.
label: BODY

text: Nondiscrimination
label: BODY

text: Qualified individuals with disabilities cannot be denied participation simply because of their disability. You can
label: BODY

text: limit participation in your course to individuals who meet some general criteria – such as being over the age of
label: BODY

text: 62 or unemployed – but if an individual qualifies on those grounds, she or he may not be denied participation
label: BODY

text: because of a disability.
label: BODY

text: Physical Access
label: BODY

text: When deciding where to hold the class, look for a location that is accessible for people who use wheelchairs or
label: BODY

text: scooters or who have other difficulties walking or climbing stairs. People with mobility limitations need to be
label: BODY

text: able to get into the building without using steps or crossing over a high object. If the main entrance is not
label: BODY

text: accessible, a sign should be posted there indicating the location of the closest accessible entrance. Classes should
label: BODY

text: be held on the upper floors of a building only if they can be reached by an elevator. The building should also
label: BODY

text: have at least one “unisex” accessible restroom.
label: BODY

text: Other physical access issues to consider in determining the location of the classrooms are clearly marked
label: BODY

text: accessible parking spaces located close to the accessible entrance, Braille signage on the elevator call buttons
label: BODY

text: and on the buttons inside the elevators, and raised letters and Braille signage identifying the restrooms. The
label: BODY

text: elevators should also have chimes or a recorded voice indicating the different floors.
label: BODY

text: In the classroom itself, check to be sure that there is at least 32 inches of clear space in the aisles and along the
label: BODY

text: edges of the seating area. This is how much space someone using a wheelchair needs to move freely around the
label: BODY

text: room. If you are using individual desks and chairs and someone who uses a wheelchair enters the room, ask that
label: BODY

text: person if you should move one of the desks or if she or he prefers to transfer from the wheelchair to the desk
label: BODY

text: chair. Always ask; never assume. People with a disability know what works best for them.
label: BODY

text: Similarly, if the room is arranged like a classroom with long tables and individual chairs, it’s always a good idea
label: BODY

text: to remove one or two of the chairs from the ends of rows in different areas of the room before the class starts, so
label: BODY

text: that individuals using wheelchairs or scooters can have a choice of seating arrangements – the same way that
label: BODY

text: others in the class have a choice about where they want to sit.
label: BODY

text: Effective Communication
label: HH3

text: Some individuals have disabilities that affect their ability to communicate – for example, people who are blind or
label: BODY

text: have low vision or people who are deaf or hearing impaired. Other disabilities that affect communication include
label: BODY

text: cognitive or learning disabilities that may impact the ability to read. People who have cognitive disabilities or
label: BODY

text: learning disabilities may have difficulty reading written material.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: Page 88 of 92
label: BODY

text: Under the ADA, both private and public entities are required to communicate effectively with individuals with
label: BODY

text: disabilities. The obligation to communicate effectively applies to the presentation and exchange of information
label: BODY

text: in all forms, including sound, print, graphics and speech.
label: BODY

text: The law says that people with communication disabilities are entitled to appropriate “aids and services where
label: BODY

text: necessary to ensure effective communications.” With respect to the Money Smart courses, these aids and
label: BODY

text: services could include:
label: BODY

text: • Assisting someone with cognitive or learning disabilities by reading aloud the pre- and post-course tests; or
label: BODY

text: • Helping someone with a disability write their answers to the tests or complete other Money Smart forms;
label: BODY

text: • Making sure not to turn your back on someone who is lip reading; or
label: BODY

text: • Wearing a lapel microphone or using a handheld microphone to amplify what is being said for persons
label: BODY

text: who use hearing aids or auxiliary listening devices; or
label: BODY

text: • Making sure that any videos used in class are captioned for people who are deaf or hard of hearing and that
label: BODY

text: written material presented on screen is read aloud, either by the narrator on the video or by the course
label: BODY

text: instructor.
label: BODY

text: Sometimes communication assistance can include providing a sign language interpreter, upon request, if doing
label: BODY

text: so does not result in an undue burden. Undue burden is defined in the ADA as “significant difficulty or
label: BODY

text: expense.” However, even if providing a sign language interpreter or some other type of communication
label: BODY

text: assistance is an undue burden, you still are expected, if at all feasible, to provide some other type of assistance,
label: BODY

text: such as a copy of the Instructor Guide, so that a person who is deaf or hard of hearing can follow along as the
label: BODY

text: class is taught.
label: BODY

text: Some people with visual disabilities have difficulty reading standard-size text or viewing materials projected on
label: BODY

text: the overhead screen. Copies of the slides for each module can be printed out and given to these individuals to
label: BODY

text: use as you present the course content. Similarly, handouts used during the course can sometimes be difficult to
label: BODY

text: handle for people who have difficulty using their hands and fingers.
label: BODY

text: Other people may have difficulty hearing what you are saying. If individuals can read lips, allow them to sit in
label: BODY

text: the front where they can have an unobstructed view of your face. If you are using an overhead projector, make
label: BODY

text: sure that you continue to face the students as you cover the major points. Keep your Instructor Manual open to
label: BODY

text: the individual slides, or, better still, print out a copy of the overhead materials so that you can read the text on
label: BODY

text: the slides without turning your head away from the person who has the hearing impairment. When there is class
label: BODY

text: discussion or when someone asks a question, repeat what has been said so that the person lip reading can be part
label: BODY

text: of the discussion.
label: BODY

text: Some individuals with significant speech disabilities use an augmentative communication device that uses a
label: BODY

text: computer to produce synthesized speech. When they want to ask a question or contribute to the class discussion,
label: BODY

text: they use a keyboard to key in what they want to say. Since keying in the content can take a few moments, you
label: BODY

text: can acknowledge their intention to speak, saying something like, “Yes, Mr. Jones, we’ll get to you as soon as
label: BODY

text: you are ready,” and then making certain that you do go back to him as soon as the keying in is completed. (Most
label: BODY

text: keyboards make a small beep as each word or phrase is keyed in.) However, during an interaction between the
label: BODY

text: person with the disability and another individual, etiquette demands that you wait respectfully until the
label: BODY

text: comments are keyed in and played.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: Page 89 of 92
label: BODY

text: Guidelines for Talking About Disabilities
label: BODY

text: Here are some guidelines that will help you communicate with your students who have disabilities in ways that
label: BODY

text: won’t offend them:
label: BODY

text: • Do not refer to a person's disability unless it is relevant.
label: BODY

text: • Use “disability” rather than “handicap” to refer to a person’s disability, if indeed you need to refer to it.
label: BODY

text: It’s okay to say that a person is handicapped by obstacles, such as architectural barriers or the attitudes of
label: BODY

text: ignorant or insensitive people. Never use “cripple/crippled” in any reference to disability.
label: BODY

text: • When referring to a person’s disability, use “people first” language. In other words, when necessary, say
label: BODY

text: “person with a disability” rather than “a disabled person”. Since “disabled” is an adjective, it’s important
label: BODY

text: to avoid ridiculous and improper constructions such as “disabled group” or “disabled transportation.’
label: BODY

text: Instead, build phrases using the word “disability.” For example, “disability activist,” or “disability
label: BODY

text: community,” are correct and not contradictions to the “people first” ideas.
label: BODY

text: • Never refer to people with disabilities as “the disabled, the blind, the epileptics, a quadriplegic,” etc.
label: BODY

text: Descriptive terms should be used as adjectives, not as nouns.
label: BODY

text: • Never use the word “retarded” or the phrase “mental retardation”. You can use “intellectual disability” or
label: BODY

text: “cognitive impairment”.
label: BODY

text: • Avoid negative or sensational descriptions of a person’s disability. Don’t say “suffers from,” “a victim
label: BODY

text: of,” or “afflicted with.” Don’t refer to people with disabilities as “patients” unless they are receiving
label: BODY

text: treatment in a medical facility. Never say “invalid.” Treat people with disabilities with respect and
label: BODY

text: acceptance.
label: BODY

text: • Don’t portray people with disabilities as overly courageous, brave, special or superhuman. This implies
label: BODY

text: that it’s unusual for people with disabilities to have talents or skills.
label: BODY

text: • Don't use “normal” to describe people who don't have disabilities. It is better to say “people without
label: BODY

text: disabilities” if necessary to make comparisons.
label: BODY

text: • Never say “wheelchair-bound” or “confined to a wheelchair.”.
label: BODY

text: • Never assume that a person with a communication disorder (speech impediment, hearing loss, motor
label: BODY

text: impairment) also has a cognitive disability.
label: BODY

text: 10 Commandments of Etiquette for Interacting with People with Disabilities
label: HH3

text: 1. When talking with a person with a disability, speak directly to that person rather than through a
label: BODY

text: companion or sign language interpreter.
label: BODY

text: 2. When introduced to a person with a disability, it is appropriate to offer to shake hands. People with limited
label: BODY

text: hand use or who wear an artificial limb can usually shake hands. (Shaking hands with the left hand is an
label: BODY

text: acceptable greeting.)
label: BODY

text: 3. When meeting a person who is visually impaired, always identify yourself and others who may be with
label: BODY

text: you. When conversing in a group, remember to identify the person to whom you are speaking.
label: BODY

text: 4. Don’t be afraid to ask questions when you're unsure of what to do. If you offer assistance, wait until the
label: BODY

text: offer is accepted. Then listen to or ask for instructions.
label: BODY

text: 5. Treat adults as adults. Address people who have disabilities by their first names only when extending the
label: BODY

text: same familiarity to all others. Never patronize people who use wheelchairs by patting them on the head or
label: BODY

text: shoulder.
label: BODY

text: 6. Leaning on or hanging on to a person’s wheelchair is similar to leaning on hanging on to a person and is
label: BODY

text: generally considered annoying. The chair is part of the personal body space of the person who uses it.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: Page 90 of 92
label: BODY

text: 7. Listen attentively when you're talking with a person who has difficulty speaking. Be patient and wait for
label: BODY

text: the person to finish, rather than correcting or speaking for the person. If necessary, ask short questions that
label: BODY

text: require short answers, a nod or shake of the head. Never pretend to understand if you are having difficulty
label: BODY

text: doing so. Instead, repeat what you have understood and allow the person to respond. The response will
label: BODY

text: clue you in and guide your understanding.
label: BODY

text: 8. When speaking with a person who uses a wheelchair or a person who uses crutches, place yourself at eye
label: BODY

text: level in front of the person to facilitate the conversation.
label: BODY

text: 9. To get the attention of a person who is deaf, tap the person on the shoulder or wave your hand. Look
label: BODY

text: directly at the person and speak clearly, slowly, and expressively to determine if the person can read your
label: BODY

text: lips. Not all people who are deaf can read lips. For those who read lips, be sensitive to their needs by
label: BODY

text: placing yourself so that you face the light source, and keep hands, cigarettes and food away from your
label: BODY

text: mouth when speaking.
label: BODY

text: 10. Relax. Don't be embarrassed if you happen to use accepted, common expressions such as “See you later,”
label: BODY

text: or “Did you hear about that?” that seem to relate to a person's disability.
label: BODY

text: MSSB Train-the-Trainer Workshop, Participant Guide
label: BODY

text: Page 91 of 92

text: Contact Information
label: H4

text: FDIC is looking forward to hearing from organizations interested in providing Money Smart for Small Business
label: BODY

text: in their communities. Feel free to reach out to FDIC Regional Office staff; you’ll find contact information on the
label: BODY

text: web at http://www.fdic.gov/consumers/community/offices.html and listed on the following pages.
label: BODY

text: You can also email FDIC at communityaffairs@fdic.gov.
label: BODY

text: When sending us a message, don’t forget to share your organization’s contact information, including a specific
label: BODY

text: Point of Contact within your organization.
label: BODY

text: Support from FDIC Community Affairs Staff is available to plan and design MSSB Train-the-Trainer Sessions
label: BODY

text: using the MSSB Curriculum and implementing the MSSB Program directly or through collaborations with
label: BODY

text: community organizations and financial institutions.
label: BODY

text: We are eager to learn about your organization and assist you in creating lasting impact within your communities.
